<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
	<head>
		<meta charset="utf-8" />
		<base href="../../../" />
		<script src="list.js"></script>
		<script src="page.js"></script>
		<link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" href="page.css" />
	</head>
	<body>
		<h1>

An efficient representation of mesh, line, or point geometry. Includes vertex positions, face indices, normals, colors, UVs, and custom attributes within buffers, reducing the cost of passing all this data to the GPU.

To read and edit data in BufferGeometry attributes, see

documentation.

For a less efficient but easier-to-use representation of geometry, see

Accessing Attributes

WebGL stores data associated with individual vertices of a geometry in attributes. Examples include the position of the vertex, the normal vector for the vertex, the vertex color, and so on. When using

takes care of wrapping
		up this information into typed array buffers and sending this data to the shader. With
		BufferGeometry, all of this data is stored in buffers associated with individual attributes.
		This means that to get the position data associated with a vertex (for instance), you must call

, then access the individual x, y, and z coordinates of the position.

The following attributes are set by various members of this class:

(itemSize: 3)

Stores the x, y, and z coordinates of each vertex in this geometry. Set by

(itemSize: 3)

Stores the x, y, and z components of the vertex normal vector of each vertex in this geometry. Set by

(itemSize: 3)

Stores the red, green, and blue channels of vertex color of each vertex in this geometry. Set by

().

In addition to the the built-in attributes, you can set your own custom attributes using the addAttribute method. With
, these attributes are set and stored on the

. In BufferGeometry, the attributes are stored with the geometry itself. Note that you still need to set the attributes information on the material as well, but the value of each attribute is stored in the BufferGeometry.

Constructor

. It also sets several properties to a default value.

Properties
This hashmap has as id the name of the attribute to be set and as value the

to set it to.
		Rather than accessing this property directly, use
to access attributes of this geometry.
Bounding box for the bufferGeometry, which can be calculated with
Bounding sphere for the bufferGeometry, which can be calculated with
Used to determine what part of the geometry should be rendered. This should not be set directly, instead use

Split the geometry into groups, each of which will be rendered in a separate WebGL draw call. This allows an array of materials to be used with the bufferGeometry.

Each group is an object of the form:

code: { start: Integer, count: Integer, materialIndex: Integer }

text:
where start specifies the first element in this draw call â€“ the first vertex for non-indexed geometry, otherwise the first triangle index. Count specifies how many vertices (or indices) are included, and materialIndex specifies the material array index to use.

Use
to add groups, rather than modifying this array directly.

For geometries that use indexed triangles, this Array can be used to split the object into multiple WebGL draw calls. Each draw call will draw some subset of the vertices in this geometry using the configured

. This may be necessary if, for instance, you have more than 65535 vertices in your object.

-->
Allows for vertices to be re-used across multiple triangles; this is called using "indexed triangles" and works much the same as it does in

: each triangle is associated with the indices of three vertices.
			This attribute therefore stores the index of each vertex for each triangular face.

			If this attribute is not set, the
assumes that each three contiguous positions represent a single triangle. Default is *null*.

Used to check whether this or derived classes are BufferGeometries. Default is *true*.

You should not change this, as it used internally for optimisation.
s holding details of the geometry's
Optional name for this bufferGeometry instance. Default is an empty string.
An object that can be used to store custom data about the BufferGeometry. It should not hold references to functions as these will not be cloned.

of this object instance. This gets automatically assigned and shouldn't be edited.

Methods
methods are available on this class.
Adds an attribute to this geometry. Use this rather than the attributes property, because an internal hashmap of
is maintained to speed up iterating over attributes.
Adds a group to this geometry; see the
Bakes matrix transform directly into vertex coordinates.
Center the geometry based on the bounding box.
Computes bounding box of the geometry, updating

attribute.
Bounding boxes aren't computed by default. They need to be explicitly computed, otherwise they are *null*.
Computes bounding sphere of the geometry, updating

attribute.
Bounding spheres aren't computed by default. They need to be explicitly computed, otherwise they are *null*.
Computes vertex normals by averaging face normals.

Disposes the object from memory.
You need to call this when you want the BufferGeometry removed while the application is running.
Populates this BufferGeometry with data from a

object containing faces. Not implemented for a line geometry.

Note:
is mainly used as an intermediary object for converting between
Populates this BufferGeometry with data from a
object containing faces. Not implemented for a line geometry.

vector - A world vector to look at.

Rotates the geometry to face a point in space. This is typically done as a one time operation, and not during a loop. Use
Merge in another BufferGeometry with an optional offset of where to start merging in.
Every normal vector in a geometry will have a magnitude of 1. This will correct lighting on the geometry surfaces.
Rotate the geometry about the X axis. This is typically done as a one time operation, and not during a loop. Use
Rotate the geometry about the Y axis. This is typically done as a one time operation, and not during a loop. Use
Rotate the geometry about the Z axis. This is typically done as a one time operation, and not during a loop. Use
Scale the geometry data. This is typically done as a one time operation, and not during a loop. Use
buffer. See that property for details.

Sets the attributes for this BufferGeometry from an array of points.
Returns a JSON object representation of the BufferGeometry.
Return a non-index version of an indexed BufferGeometry.
Translate the geometry. This is typically done as a one time operation, and not during a loop. Use
